schulte.title: The Useful Field of View (UFOV)
schulte.description:
The Useful Field of View (UFOV) research proves that peripheral vision training expands the brain's ability to process visual information faster and improves attention quality.

üìñ Ball, K. & Owsley, C. (1993). 'The useful field of view: A new technique for evaluating age-related declines in visual attention.' Psychology and Aging.

This research shows that regular UFOV training expands visual attention span and enables processing peripheral objects up to 35% faster.

saccadic.title: Saccadic Eye Movements in Reading
saccadic.description:
This groundbreaking study by Professor Keith Rayner scientifically proves that the main factors limiting reading speed are incorrect saccades and regressions (backward eye movements).

üìñ Rayner, K. (1998). 'Eye movements in reading and information processing: 20 years of research.' Psychological Bulletin.

This training targets 'return sweep' movements (transitioning from line end to new line start), reducing regressions by up to 40% and improving reading fluency.
